results.title: Beginning
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merry-Go-Round Sex Education. - Part 1.”.
The first in a three part series of sex-education films for young children, “Beginning” uses cross references in the animal world to explain embryonic growth and development. A microscope shows the process of cell division in the egg, and animated drawings reveal the embryo’s position in the body. Method of nourishment, and developmental changes to five months.

group_works.title: Birth. - Rev. ed.
group_works.creator_credit: Claire Chovil, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Birth. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Claire Chovil, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Merry-go-round”.
Birth describes the steps in child delivery and the special characteristics of the new born. Simple drawings and other references to the animal world explain the general birth process, while animated illustrations showing the movement of the human embryo provide details on labour and anatomy. One sequence allows the viewer to witness the actual moment of a baby’s birth and the steps that follow. Commentary by Richard Carpenter, Melissa Docker. Animation by Barry Merritt. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Variations V
results.creator_credit: Arne Arnbom and Studio Hamburg, Nordeutscher Rundfunk
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
A multi-media dance work involving twelve sound sensitive electronic poles placed around the stage performed by members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. The sound is triggered by the dancer’s movements and then altered or delayed by the musicians. Filmmaker Stan Van Der Beek recorded rehearsals of the dancers and then overlayed this footage as well as other stock footage images in the final film. Composer Nam June Paik projected these images on television screens during the performance. Non-dance related activities were also performed. Merce Cunningham potted a large plant and Carolyn Brown repotted it. The plant had a microphone attached to it so that any movement would produce sound. At the end of the piece, Merce Cunningham rode a bicycle through the space. Choreography by Merce Cunningham. Music by John Cage. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arne Arnbom and Studio Hamburg, Nordeutscher Rundfunk

results.title: Beach birds for camera
results.creator_credit: Merce Cunningham, Elliot Caplan and Cunningham Dance Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
Beach birds for camera is a version for film of the dance “Beach birds”. It is in that sense a different piece from the stage production as the title suggests because of the medium used - film and all of its implied language. Merce Cunningham introduces the dance and extrapolates on his exploration of film as a medium for presentation and how the language of film affects the reading and possibilities of the production. Cunningham explores the language of film expressing this through change and use of the human body. Movement and time as with the use of the camera is an extension of the use of the human body. Cast is made from members from the Merce Cunningham Company with music by John Cage.

results.title: CRWDSPCR
results.creator_credit: Elliot Caplan and Cunningham Dance Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
CRWDSPCR features the choreographic process of Merce Cunningham’s work with the computer program “LifeForms”. Cunningham, an inveterate explorer of new technology, became interested in “how the computer opens the eye to detail — the way a photograph does.” Shot over the course of one year, CRWDSPCR follows the dancers from Cunningham’s dance company as they transform his computerized images to staged reality. Music by John King. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html

results.title: Blue studio: five segments
results.creator_credit: Charles Atlas, Merce Cunningham and Cunningham Dance Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
Merce Cunningham directed and performed a number of dance works in the 1970’s that dealt specifically with the language and aesthetic of film. “Blue studio” is one of these works that Cunningham made that directly utilised filmic devices interacting with the physical human body to create a series of avant garde works that are housed within the screen. Working with film enabled Cunningham to create pieces not possible for the stage, utilising blue screen technology, animation, editing and the layering of various film stock. This approach to his work changes both the contextual and physical aspects possible in dance whilst addressing the human and physical relationship with television. “Camera space presents a challenge. It has clear limits, but it also gives opportunities of working with dance that are not available on the stage. The camera takes a fixed view, but it can be moved. There is the possibility of cutting to a second camera which can change the size of the dancer, which, to my eye, also affects the time, the rhythm of the movement…” Merce Cunningham. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles Atlas, Merce Cunningham and Cunningham Dance Foundation

results.title: Camera three: a video event parts I and II
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
In the Spring of 1974, Merrill Brockway produced two half hour programs featuring Merce Cunningham and his company. The programs were only aired twice that year and were not seen again for twenty-five years. These two programs contain important archival material from the early 1960s and 1970s. Excerpts of performances of “Winterbranch”, “Second Hand”, Sounddance”, “TV Rerun”, “Changing Steps”, “Landrover”, and “Signals are included. Throughout the programs, Cunningham discusses his ideas and approach to dancing. Choreography by Merce Cunningham. Music by Christian Wolff. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html

results.title: Cage/Cunningham
results.creator_credit: Elliot Caplan, La Sept and Cunningham Dance Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
Feature length documentary portrait tracing the history of the collaboration of choreographer, Merce Cunningham, and composer, John Cage, which spanned nearly fifty years beginning at the Cornish Institute of Allied Arts in Seattle, Washington. In telling the story of Cunningham and Cage, award winning filmmaker and Cunningham collaborator, Elliot Caplan, utilizes candid footage of their activities around the world since 1983, rare footage from the Cunningham and Cage archives, and interviews with principal figures involved in the collaboration. Caplan’s daily contact with Cage and Cunningham has inspired a revealing and sensitive portrait of two men whose spirit of adventure and iconoclastic thinking have helped to revolutionize life, as well as art in the twentieth century. Includes interviews with Nam June Paik, Robert Rauschenberg, Carolyn Brown, Viola Farber and Rudolf Nureyev. Choreography by Merce Cunningham. Music by John Cage. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elliot Caplan, La Sept and Cunningham Dance Foundation
